import React from 'react'; import {Link} from "react-router-dom"; import ExternalLink from './ExternalLink'; import EnsembleImage from '../images/ensemble-project.png'; import Research1 from '../images/research 1.png'; import Research2 from '../images/research 2.png'; import Iteration1 from '../images/iteration 1.png'; import Iteration2 from '../images/iteration 2.png'; import FinalIteration from '../images/final iteration.png'; function EnsembleProject() { return(

Designing Truist Trade: Truist's first all-digital brokerage account

8 min read  //  July 2021 - November 2022

My Role

Product designer + design strategist. Responsible for setting design strategy and servicing all account opening UI/UX needs for the duration of the project.

Project Team

Product Manager, Product Owner, Business Strategists, Researchers, Content Strategist, Service Designer, Project Manager

Tools I Used

Axure, Figma, Miro

Background

In July 2021 I embarked on a journey to create Truist Trade, Truist's first all-digital, self-serve brokerage account. At first, I thought this would be a simple, straightforward project. Truist already had online account opening experiences for many other products - from checking accounts to small business loans. I felt that we'd simply be adding one more product to our portfolio. Little did I know that Truist Trade project would become the largest, most complicated, and most rewarding design project of my career so far.

What is Truist Trade?

Truist Trade is an all-digital brokerage account that Truist (the 7th largest bank in the U.S. at the time of writing) launched on November 14, 2022. I designed the entire account opening experience - which you can check out !

Another brokerage account? Why?

One of the very first things I sought out to do when I joined Truist was to learn the “why” behind the project. So many firms already offered brokerage accounts - Robinhood, E*TRADE, Charles Schwab, to name a few. How could we possibly hope to compete in such a crowded market?

I learned that our strategy wasn't necessarily to attract new customers to the bank - but rather to retain existing ones. People who banked with Truist wanted to invest with us too. But because our current offerings were lackluster (opening a brokerage account required calling an advisor and paying $15 per trade!), customers were taking their money elsewhere. To retain these customers, we needed to give them a way to invest with the convenience and digital capabilities that they expected.

A significant amount of research was conducted prior to my arrival to understand the needs and behaviours of our target audience. We eventually distilled this research into archetypes, which I referenced throughout the design process.

Challenge 1: Charting a path forward.

Early on, one of the biggest challenges with Truist Trade was figuring out where to start. This project already had quite a history. It had been in various stages of development for a couple years, and this latest iteration had formally kicked off several months before I joined the team.

This slide was one of the more actionable artifacts from the existing research. It depicts 21 solution opportunities - based on research - that our team should solve for to create the ideal investing experience.

Despite the project's history, no progress had been made in designing or implementing the product. The team was stuck. We needed to find a way to move from ideation to execution.

To help us move forward, I started sketching design concepts. While I realized that this work would likely get thrown out as the project evolved, I figured that having a more tangible representation of our vision could help us socialize the project and get buy-in.

My early design work took on two forms - user flow diagrams (to help us understand the scope), and mid-fidelity wireframes (to determine what information was needed from the user at each step). For complex projects, I always start with flow diagrams. I find them to be immensely helpful, both for understanding the scope and sharing the “big picture” with stakeholders.

Challenge 2: Making the best experience possible within technical and time constraints

Eventually, we were given the green light to proceed. I had 6 months to deliver high-fidelity mock-ups for the entire account opening journey. To ensure I could deliver the necessary work in time, I used two time-management techniques:

Technique #1

I identified the most important parts of the account opening journey. These were the steps that I would spend most of my time and our research resources on.

Technique #2

For the less important steps, I re-used existing designs from other products' account opening experiences.

Important part 1: Choosing the right account

I could write an essay describing what happens next - detailing all of the nitty gritty details of each and every part of Truist Trade, but in the interest of time (and retaining your attention), I'll focus on a few key parts of the experience.

One of the most important steps in the process is also one of the first - picking an account to open. From analyzing the fallout rates of other products, we knew that many potential customers abandoned the application during the first 1-3 screens. We needed to “hook” them right from the start to encourage them to complete the application.

Hook #1

Build trust. Research taught us that an individual's trust in a financial instutition plays a huge role in determining whether they'll invest with that institution. I sought to build trust with users by showing clear and transparent information about the product and the process they'd need to go through to open it.

Hook #2

Keep it simple. I kept the first three screens relatively short and clutter-free to give the impression that the process would be fast and easy.

Providing sufficient information was especially important on the account selection page, where users must choose which accounts they would like to open. Finding the right balance of information was especially tricky - we needed to show enough to educate newbie investors but not too much to overwhelm them. Below you can see several of the iterations I went through before arriving at the final design.

One of the earliest iterations of the account selection page. Initially I experimented with using badges to denote accounts that were better for retirement. While this tested well, we had to scrap it for legal reasons. Since Truist Trade is a self-directed brokerage account, we can't show content that could be construed as giving advice.

This iteration was created after legal review and a round of usability testing. Notable changes are the shift from pro/cons for each account to simply listing the benefits (users didn't like that each account in the first iteration seemed to have downsides), the addition of FAQs (newer investors wanted more information), and a better way to contact customer service.

The final version, currently in production. FAQs were moved to tooltips to improve accessibility. A sub headline was added to clarify that multiple accounts can be opened at once.

Important part 2: Help on demand

Another part of the journey that I spent a significant amount of time tweaking and refining was the process of getting help. Investing is complex. When customers have questions, they expect answers in a timely fashion.

Truist had an established design pattern for getting help online, but it wasn't sufficient. Customers struggled to find a number to call for help. Even if they found and called the number, they were faced with long wait times and reaching people who couldn't even answer their questions. We needed a better way.

The new design improved findability by replacing the hamburger menu with a recognizable icon and a label. We observed that users found our customer service number in this design 75% faster compared to the original design. Wait times were also very positively received, though this was ultimately tabled since it wasn't feasible for us to display it when Truist Trade launched.

The original design pattern buried the help options in a hamburger menu. I learned that this was done intentionally to reduce call volumes. Talk about user-centered design!

Thanks for reading!

); } export default EnsembleProject;
